HED|Uprising in Egypt; Mubarak Shuts Down Al Jazeera
LAN|ENG
LBT|2011-01-30 08:00 America/Los_Angeles
20110130160007.000|20110130165948.000|SEG|Type=Story
20110130160007.000|20110130160009.000|TR0|HOWARD KURTZ, HOST:  There is breaking 
20110130160009.000|20110130160011.000|TR0|news this morning, as Egyptian authorities 
20110130160011.000|20110130160013.000|TR0|have shut down the offices of Al Jazeera.  
20110130160013.000|20110130160015.000|TR0|We'll ask a top executive why the Mubarak 
20110130160015.000|20110130160017.000|TR0|government has retaliated against the Arab 
20110130160017.000|20110130160019.000|TR0|satellite channel.
20110130160019.000|20110130160021.000|TR0|
20110130160021.000|20110130160023.000|TR0|The uprising in Egypt not only took the 
20110130160023.000|20110130160025.000|TR0|world by surprise, it strained the 
20110130160025.000|20110130160027.000|TR0|resources of a media establishment that 
20110130160027.000|20110130160029.000|TR0|has cut way back on national coverage in 
20110130160029.000|20110130160032.000|TR0|places like Tunisia and Egypt.  We'll 
20110130160032.000|20110130160034.000|TR0|examine the challenges of keeping pace 
20110130160034.000|20110130160036.000|TR0|with this fast-moving story and how 
20110130160036.000|20110130160038.000|TR0|Cairo's authoritarian regime has tried to 
20110130160038.000|20110130160040.000|TR0|undermine the street protests by shutting 
20110130160040.000|20110130160042.000|TR0|down Facebook, Twitter and the Internet 
20110130160042.000|20110130160044.000|TR0|itself.
20110130160044.000|20110130160046.000|TR0|
20110130160046.000|20110130160048.000|TR0|Plus, CNN takes some heat for airing 
20110130160048.000|20110130160050.000|TR0|Michele Bachmann's speech to a Tea Party 
20110130160050.000|20110130160052.000|TR0|group which was not the official 
20110130160052.000|20110130160054.000|TR0|Republican response to the State of the 
20110130160054.000|20110130160057.000|TR0|Union.  Did she deserve the air time?
20110130160057.000|20110130160059.000|TR0|
20110130160059.000|20110130160101.000|TR0|And President Obama names Jay Carney, a 
20110130160101.000|20110130160103.000|TR0|career journalist, as his new spokesman.  
20110130160103.000|20110130160105.000|TR0|Can a former "TIME" magazine reporter tame 
20110130160105.000|20110130160107.000|TR0|the jackals of the press?
20110130160107.000|20110130160109.000|TR0|
20110130160109.000|20110130160111.000|TR0|I'm Howard Kurtz, and this is RELIABLE 
20110130160111.000|20110130160113.000|TR0|SOURCES.
20110130160113.000|20110130160115.000|TR0|
20110130160115.000|20110130160117.000|TR0|There are fewer Western journalists in the 
20110130160117.000|20110130160120.000|TR0|Middle East today than a decade or two 
20110130160120.000|20110130160122.000|TR0|ago, but that's not the only reason the 
20110130160122.000|20110130160124.000|TR0|political explosion in Egypt took just 
20110130160124.000|20110130160126.000|TR0|about everyone by surprise.  Hosni 
20110130160126.000|20110130160128.000|TR0|Mubarak's regime has always been portrayed 
20110130160128.000|20110130160130.000|TR0|in the press as stable. The country never 
20110130160130.000|20110130160132.000|TR0|before seen as a simmering (INAUDIBLE) of 
20110130160132.000|20110130160134.000|TR0|tension.
20110130160134.000|20110130160136.000|TR0|
20110130160136.000|20110130160138.000|TR0|But as tens of thousands poured into the 
20110130160138.000|20110130160140.000|TR0|Cairo streets, news organizations tried 
20110130160140.000|20110130160142.000|TR0|strenuously to cover and make sense of the 
20110130160142.000|20110130160145.000|TR0|fast- moving events.  That challenge made 
20110130160145.000|20110130160147.000|TR0|considerably harder by the government 
20110130160147.000|20110130160149.000|TR0|shutting down Internet and, for a time, 
20110130160149.000|20110130160151.000|TR0|limiting satellite and cell phone service.
20110130160151.000|20110130160153.000|TR0|
20110130160153.000|20110130160155.000|TR0|An Egyptian journalist for the BBC 
20110130160155.000|20110130160157.000|TR0|describes what happened to him.
20110130160157.000|20110130160159.000|TR0|
20110130160159.000|20110130160201.000|TR0|(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
20110130160201.000|20110130160203.000|TR0|
20110130160203.000|20110130160205.000|TR0|ASSAD SAWEY, REPORTER, BBC ARABIC:  They 
20110130160205.000|20110130160208.000|TR0|were targeting journalists deliberately.  
20110130160208.000|20110130160210.000|TR0|They took my camera.  And when they 
20110130160210.000|20110130160212.000|TR0|arrested me, they started beating me up 
20110130160212.000|20110130160214.000|TR0|with steel bars, the ones used here for 
20110130160214.000|20110130160216.000|TR0|animals, for slaughtering animals.
20110130160216.000|20110130160218.000|TR0|
20110130160218.000|20110130160220.000|TR0|And it's been really, really brutal.  
20110130160220.000|20110130160222.000|TR0|Police are very, very brutal.  I'm going 
20110130160222.000|20110130160224.000|TR0|to hospital shortly.

20110130160517.000|20110130160520.000|TR0|down on the Internet -- and I have read 
20110130160520.000|20110130160522.000|TR0|estimates that 93 percent of Egyptians can

20110130160524.000|20110130160526.000|TR0|that ban been?  How is it that some

20110130160530.000|20110130160532.000|TR0|
20110130160532.000|20110130160534.000|TR0|MOHAMMED JAMJOOM, CNN INTERNATIONAL 
20110130160534.000|20110130160536.000|TR0|CORRESPONDENT:  Well, Howard, it's been 
20110130160536.000|20110130160538.000|TR0|fascinating to see basically what the 
20110130160538.000|20110130160540.000|TR0|reaction was after the shutdown, because 
20110130160540.000|20110130160542.000|TR0|what you were seeing was not just people 
20110130160542.000|20110130160545.000|TR0|in the region, but people worldwide, 
20110130160545.000|20110130160547.000|TR0|online activism movements that were 
20110130160547.000|20110130160549.000|TR0|basically tweeting out and putting out 
20110130160549.000|20110130160551.000|TR0|social media messages for the Egyptian 
20110130160551.000|20110130160553.000|TR0|people on how they could circumvent the 
20110130160553.000|20110130160555.000|TR0|Internet blockage, because as you said, 
20110130160555.000|20110130160557.000|TR0|it's about 93 percent blocked, it has been 
20110130160557.000|20110130160559.000|TR0|since Thursday, in the overnight hours, 
20110130160559.000|20110130160601.000|TR0|and it doesn't look like it's getting 
20110130160601.000|20110130160603.000|TR0|better any time soon.
20110130160603.000|20110130160605.000|TR0|
20110130160605.000|20110130160608.000|TR0|We were seeing people tweeting from places 
20110130160608.000|20110130160610.000|TR0|like Yemen, where there isn't a lot of 
20110130160610.000|20110130160612.000|TR0|Twitter activity, giving numbers for ISPs 
20110130160612.000|20110130160614.000|TR0|in France so that people could use dial-up 
20110130160614.000|20110130160616.000|TR0|modems to get back online.  A lot of 
20110130160616.000|20110130160618.000|TR0|online activists have been putting out 
20110130160618.000|20110130160620.000|TR0|messages on other ways they can do it, 
20110130160620.000|20110130160622.000|TR0|maybe even using Ham radio technology so 
20110130160622.000|20110130160624.000|TR0|that people in Egypt could continue to get 
20110130160624.000|20110130160626.000|TR0|the message out via social media even 
20110130160626.000|20110130160628.000|TR0|though the Internet was blocked.  So it's 
20110130160628.000|20110130160630.000|TR0|just been absolutely fascinating to see 
20110130160630.000|20110130160633.000|TR0|this -- Howard.
20110130160633.000|20110130160635.000|TR0|
20110130160635.000|20110130160637.000|TR0|KURTZ:  People can be very inventive when 
20110130160637.000|20110130160639.000|TR0|they need to be.
20110130160639.000|20110130160641.000|TR0|

20110130160656.000|20110130160658.000|TR0|
20110130160658.000|20110130160700.000|TR0|So, is Internet access now a human right?

20110130160702.000|20110130160704.000|TR0|JEFFREY JARVIS, "BUZZ MACHINE":  I think 
20110130160704.000|20110130160706.000|TR0|it's exactly that, Howard.  And it's 
20110130160706.000|20110130160708.000|TR0|somewhat ironic in the fact that the U.S. 
20110130160708.000|20110130160710.000|TR0|government has been trying to shut down 
20110130160710.000|20110130160712.000|TR0|WikiLeaks.
20110130160712.000|20110130160714.000|TR0|
20110130160714.000|20110130160716.000|TR0|I think that the right to connect now 
20110130160716.000|20110130160718.000|TR0|becomes a fundamental human right, and the 
20110130160718.000|20110130160721.000|TR0|problem here, as we see, that government 
20110130160721.000|20110130160723.000|TR0|is the single point of failure for the 
20110130160723.000|20110130160725.000|TR0|Internet, whether that's the kill switch, 
20110130160725.000|20110130160727.000|TR0|as Egypt has used it, or whether that's 
20110130160727.000|20110130160729.000|TR0|the fact that they control the structure

20110130160731.000|20110130160733.000|TR0|
20110130160733.000|20110130160735.000|TR0|And so our future, the means by which

20110130160739.000|20110130160741.000|TR0|the same time, I celebrate the fact that 
20110130160741.000|20110130160744.000|TR0|our people in a nation can use these tools

20110130160815.000|20110130160817.000|TR0|words, trying to suppress this revolution

20110130160844.000|20110130160846.000|TR0|summit.  And it's not a fun place to be,

20110130160901.000|20110130160903.000|TR0|Kentucky Fried Chicken which was then

20110130160934.000|20110130160936.000|TR0|
20110130160936.000|20110130160938.000|TR0|LT. COL. RALPH PETERS, FOX NEWS 
20110130160938.000|20110130160940.000|TR0|CONTRIBUTOR:  Mubarak has conned us.  He's 
20110130160940.000|20110130160942.000|TR0|done stuff for us, but we've done a lot 
20110130160942.000|20110130160945.000|TR0|more for him.  We've helped him stay in

20110130162748.000|20110130162750.000|TR0|
20110130162750.000|20110130162752.000|TR0|FOUKARA:  Well, look, what's -- the 
20110130162752.000|20110130162754.000|TR0|coverage of Al Jazeera is being criticized 
20110130162754.000|20110130162756.000|TR0|by some governments, it's being criticized 
20110130162756.000|20110130162758.000|TR0|by people outside of the United States.  
20110130162758.000|20110130162800.000|TR0|But to the people who are actually 
20110130162800.000|20110130162802.000|TR0|demonstrating, whether in Tunis or in 
20110130162802.000|20110130162804.000|TR0|Cairo or in Yemen or in Jordan, is a 
20110130162804.000|20110130162806.000|TR0|source of reliable information not only if 
20110130162806.000|20110130162808.000|TR0|what goes on in their own countries, but 
20110130162808.000|20110130162811.000|TR0|what goes on in the neighborhood.
20110130162811.000|20110130162813.000|TR0|
20110130162813.000|20110130162815.000|TR0|So we may differ with certain governments 
20110130162815.000|20110130162817.000|TR0|on the definition of what trustworthy 
20110130162817.000|20110130162819.000|TR0|coverage is.  The fact of the situation is 
20110130162819.000|20110130162821.000|TR0|that the viewership, the people who are 
20110130162821.000|20110130162823.000|TR0|directly involved in these events, they 
20110130162823.000|20110130162825.000|TR0|come to Al Jazeera because that's where 
20110130162825.000|20110130162827.000|TR0|they feel with some trust they can air 
20110130162827.000|20110130162829.000|TR0|their grievances and their aspirations.
20110130162829.000|20110130162831.000|TR0|
20110130162831.000|20110130162834.000|TR0|KURTZ:  Ironically, one of the reasons 
20110130162834.000|20110130162836.000|TR0|that Al Jazeera is barely a presence on 
20110130162836.000|20110130162838.000|TR0|the airwaves in the United States is 
20110130162838.000|20110130162840.000|TR0|because of criticism that it's been 
20110130162840.000|20110130162842.000|TR0|pro-Arab and anti-American.  I'm sure you 
20110130162842.000|20110130162844.000|TR0|would reject that, but, of course, the 
20110130162844.000|20110130162846.000|TR0|Arab position is not always uniform, as 
20110130162846.000|20110130162848.000|TR0|we're seeing in Egypt.
20110130162848.000|20110130162850.000|TR0|
20110130162850.000|20110130162852.000|TR0|Is it fair to say your journalists are not 
20110130162852.000|20110130162854.000|TR0|only better connected with, say, those 
20110130162854.000|20110130162856.000|TR0|involved in this Egyptian protest, but are 
20110130162856.000|20110130162859.000|TR0|sympathetic to those who are trying to 
20110130162859.000|20110130162901.000|TR0|topple what has been an authoritarian 
20110130162901.000|20110130162903.000|TR0|regime for nearly three decades?
20110130162903.000|20110130162905.000|TR0|
20110130162905.000|20110130162907.000|TR0|FOUKARA:  Well, the viewership, but 
20110130162907.000|20110130162909.000|TR0|certainly the protesters -- look, Al 
20110130162909.000|20110130162911.000|TR0|Jazeera has invested in gaining the trust 
20110130162911.000|20110130162913.000|TR0|of its viewers around the Middle East for 
20110130162913.000|20110130162915.000|TR0|over a decade.
20110130162915.000|20110130162917.000|TR0|
20110130162917.000|20110130162919.000|TR0|KURTZ:  You're there all the time, not 
20110130162919.000|20110130162922.000|TR0|just --
20110130162922.000|20110130162924.000|TR0|
20110130162924.000|20110130162926.000|TR0|(CROSSTALK)
20110130162926.000|20110130162928.000|TR0|
20110130162928.000|20110130162930.000|TR0|FOUKARA:  We're there all the time.  In 
20110130162930.000|20110130162932.000|TR0|times of crisis, I mean, even in Egypt, 
20110130162932.000|20110130162934.000|TR0|you would see that local television 
20110130162934.000|20110130162936.000|TR0|stations can compete and have been able to 
20110130162936.000|20110130162938.000|TR0|compete with Al Jazeera in normal times. 
20110130162938.000|20110130162940.000|TR0|But in times of crisis, whether it's the 
20110130162940.000|20110130162942.000|TR0|situation in Tunisia, or in Gaza, or in 
20110130162942.000|20110130162944.000|TR0|Iraq, most of them flock to Al Jazeera.
20110130162944.000|20110130162947.000|TR0|

20110130163757.000|20110130163759.000|TR0|newsy and over the top.  But I think 
20110130163759.000|20110130163801.000|TR0|there's a serious point here, too, which 
20110130163801.000|20110130163803.000|TR0|is that she represents what is a broader 
20110130163803.000|20110130163805.000|TR0|story about the divisions within the 
20110130163805.000|20110130163807.000|TR0|Republican Party.  And there's serious 
20110130163807.000|20110130163809.000|TR0|divisions.  It's going to be a story from

20110130165744.000|20110130165746.000|TR0|show that he was responding to an ugly 
20110130165746.000|20110130165749.000|TR0|remark about Nancy Reagan by some

20110130165853.000|20110130165855.000|TR0|By the way, MSNBC taking a step towards 
20110130165855.000|20110130165857.000|TR0|civility after Keith Olbermann's 
20110130165857.000|20110130165900.000|TR0|departure.  The network is ending Ed 
20110130165900.000|20110130165902.000|TR0|Schultz' "Psycho Talk" segment in which 
20110130165902.000|20110130165904.000|TR0|the host accuses various conservatives of 
20110130165904.000|20110130165906.000|TR0|being kind of crazy.
20110130165906.000|20110130165908.000|TR0|
20110130165908.000|20110130165910.000|TR0|This wasn't voluntary.  Schultz says, "I 
20110130165910.000|20110130165912.000|TR0|work for somebody and I don't call the 
20110130165912.000|20110130165914.000|TR0|shots."
20110130165914.000|20110130165916.000|TR0|
20110130165916.000|20110130165918.000|TR0|"Psycho Talk" is history.
